title: Problem Overview
content: **Erdős Problem #732** studies block-compatible sequences - sequences of block sizes that can arise from pairwise balanced block designs. A PBD partitions all pairs {i,j} from {1,...,n} into blocks, with each pair in exactly one block. The problem asks (1) to characterize which sequences are block-compatible, and (2) to count how many exist.
mathContext: Erdős posed this in 1981. He proved the upper bound on the count. Alon later proved the matching lower bound, resolving Q2. The characterization problem Q1 remains open.

title: Block
content:
**Block Definition:**

A block is simply a subset of {1, ..., n}.

In a PBD, blocks partition the set of all pairs.

title: IsPBD
content:
**Pairwise Balanced Block Design:**

A PBD is a collection of blocks A₁, ..., Aₘ ⊆ {1,...,n} such that every pair {i,j} is contained in exactly one block Aₖ.

This is the key structural constraint.

title: IsBlockCompatible
content:
**Block-Compatible Sequence:**

A sequence Xs = [X₁, ..., Xₘ] is block-compatible for n if there exists a PBD on {1,...,n} whose block sizes (in order) equal Xs.

This links sequences to combinatorial designs.

title: PairCountCondition
content:
**Pair-Counting Condition:**

Σᵢ C(Xᵢ, 2) = C(n, 2)

Each block of size k covers C(k,2) pairs. Since all C(n,2) pairs must be covered exactly once, this sum must equal the total.

This is NECESSARY but NOT SUFFICIENT.

title: pair_count_necessary
content:
**Necessity Theorem:**

If Xs is block-compatible for n, then Xs satisfies the pair-counting condition.

**Proof idea:** Each pair is covered exactly once, so total pair-coverage equals total pairs.

title: characterization_hard
content:
**No Simple Characterization:**

There exist sequences satisfying pair-counting that are NOT block-compatible.

This shows pair-counting is not sufficient, and finding a complete characterization is subtle.

title: B
content:
**Counting Function:**

B(n) = number of block-compatible sequences for n.

This is the central quantity for Question 2.

title: erdos_upper_bound
content:
**Erdős's Upper Bound:**

B(n) ≤ exp(O(√n · log n))

Erdős proved there cannot be too many block-compatible sequences.

title: alon_lower_bound
content:
**Alon's Lower Bound:**

B(n) ≥ 2^((1/2 + o(1))√n · log n)

Alon showed exponentially many sequences ARE block-compatible.

This SOLVES Question 2 affirmatively.

title: question_2_solved
content:
**Question 2: SOLVED**

There exists c > 0 such that B(n) ≥ exp(c·√n·log n) for large n.

**Proof:** Take c = (1/3)·ln(2). By Alon's bound with ε = 1/6:
B(n) ≥ 2^((1/3)√n·log n) = exp((1/3)·ln(2)·√n·log n)

title: AsymptoticConstant
content:
**The Asymptotic:**

B(n) = 2^((c + o(1))√n · log n)

Alon shows c ≥ 1/2, Erdős shows c ≤ O(1).

The exact constant may not be determined.

title: Example n=3
content:
**n = 3 Example:**

The only PBD on {1,2,3} is the single block {1,2,3}.

Block-compatible sequence: [3]

C(3,2) = 3 pairs, all covered by one block.

title: Example n=4
content:
**n = 4 Example:**

C(4,2) = 6 pairs needed.

Possible block-compatible sequences:
- [4]: Single block, C(4,2) = 6 ✓
- [2,2,2,2,2,2]: Six pairs, 6×C(2,2) = 6×1 = 6 ✓

Both satisfy pair-counting.

title: Steiner Systems
content:
**Connection to Steiner Systems:**

A Steiner system S(2, k, n) is a PBD where ALL blocks have the same size k.

These are very constrained and exist only for special parameters.

title: erdos_732_summary
content:
**Complete Summary:**

**QUESTION 1:** Characterize block-compatible sequences.
- STATUS: OPEN
- Pair-counting is necessary but not sufficient

**QUESTION 2:** Is B(n) ≥ exp(c·√n·log n)?
- STATUS: SOLVED by Alon
- B(n) ≈ 2^((1/2+o(1))√n·log n)

**KEY INSIGHT:** Exponentially many block-compatible sequences exist, but identifying which specific sequences work remains hard.
